body:
### Problem Treesitter highlight works incorrectly with some certain queries with predicates. This example was brought by an user `refp`: Language: `go`
With the following query, whose intention is to capture highlight a string in some function call with `@sql` when the method name is `Query`: ```query ((call_expression (selector_expression field: (field_identifier) @_field) (argument_list [ (raw_string_literal) (interpreted_string_literal) ] @sql)) (#eq? @_field "Query") ; (#offset! @sql 0 0 0 0); <----------- note this hack [optional] ) ``` This should match only for `db.Query("SELECT ...")`, but NOT for `db.NotQuery("SELECT ...")`. But treesitter is returning two captures as shown in the screenshot. What's strange is, **when we add the directive** ``` (#offset! @sql 0 0 0 0) ``` which semantically does nothing, *it works*: the capture group is correct. Please see the minimal reproduction below. This bug could be either: - a bug of neovim (in `treesitter.c` code) - or a bug of the upstream tree-sitter Related to #23664 but slightly different (it's not about metadata, `match` being incorrect), probably sharing the same root cause. ### Steps to reproduce Have a go parser installed on VIMRUNTIME. ```lua -- 笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏―r -- 1. Prepare parser (tree) and the query. -- 笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏―r local code = [[ db.Query("INTERPRETED STRING") db.NotQuery(`RAW STRING`) ]] -- lang:go local parser = vim.treesitter.get_string_parser(code, 'go', {}) ---@type LanguageTree local tree = parser:parse()[1] ---@type TSTree local root = tree:root() ---@type TSNode local query = [[ ((call_expression (selector_expression field: (field_identifier) @_field) (argument_list [ (raw_string_literal) (interpreted_string_literal) ] @sql)) (#eq? @_field "Query") ; (#offset! @sql 0 0 0 0); <----------- note this hack [optional] ) ]] ---@type Query local ts_query = vim.treesitter.query.parse('go', query) -- vim.print(ts_query) -- { -- captures = <1>{ "_field", "sql" }, -- info = { -- captures = , -- patterns = { { -- { "any-of?", 1, "Query" }, -- { "offset!", 2, "0", "0", "0", "0" } -- <--------------- optional -- } } -- }, -- ... -- } -- 笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏―r -- 2. Execute the query and get all the captures. -- 笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏≫煤笏―r for capture_id, node, metadata in ts_query:iter_captures(root, code, 0, 3) do ---@cast node TSNode ---@cast metadata TSMetadata local name = ts_query.captures[capture_id] local node_text = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, code, { metadata = metadata }) vim.print(('id=%d @%-8s : node = %s'):format(capture_id, name, node_text)) end -- Result (BUG!) there is an errorneous match. -- id=1 @_field : node = Query -- id=2 @sql : node = "INTERPRETED STRING" -- id=2 @sql : node = `RAW STRING` <---------- should not match. -- Result with (#offset! @sql 0 0 0 0) enabled: correctly captures only one `@sql` match -- id=1 @_field : node = Query -- id=2 @sql : node = "INTERPRETED STRING" ``` ### Expected behavior
(Folded: with the `dummy` directive applied)
Correct result: only one capture is returned for `@sql`. ```diff -- id=1 @_field : node = Query -- id=2 @sql : node = "INTERPRETED STRING" ``` But the above code gives an erroneous capture: ```diff -- id=1 @_field : node = Query -- id=2 @sql : node = "INTERPRETED STRING" --- id=2 @sql : node = `RAW STRING` <---------- should not match. ``` ### Neovim version (nvim -v) 0.10-HEAD 2cd76a758
Other details (irrelevant) ### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same? N/A ### Operating system/version macOS 14 ### Terminal name/version doesn't matter ### $TERM environment variable xterm-256color ### Installation build from source

comment_data.body:
Thank you very much, both for the assistance in figuring out this odd behavior - but also for helping me understand more about tree-sitter! @wookayin :muscle:

Perhaps this is the start of some contributions from me, I surely got inspired messing around (even though I seem to have been unlucky in what I tested and in what order, a lot learnt though)!

I remember similar reports in the past, e.g., https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/20948.

Might also be related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23664 (wrong metadata with multiple captures).

> My question is: Is the behavior of query_next_capture [returning only 2 values: [index, node]](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/v0.9.5/src/nvim/lua/treesitter.c#L1334), match being nil intended?

I believe this is not the case, if the code is that old. This situation just wasn't considered, most likely.

> An iterator TSNode:_rawquery() would enumerate "captures" (capture_id: integer, node: TSNode, match: TSMatch)

> - First, match is nil from the second capture.
> - Second, the same instance of match Lua table is returned across different matches.

> This bug has existed since the first implementation https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/440695c29696f261337227e5c419aa1cf313c2dd of treesitter.

if one only were to go a little step further, and consider these two points _together_ , it would almost look like it was intentional at the time: 

- As the `match` table only was used _once_ to filter out based one predicates, and it wasn't used to keep track of the "identity" of a match, there was no need original to allocate extra memory for every single match that immediately would have become GC garbage to clean up.

Of course it is perfectly fine to change the code if we now _need_ that information. But that old code didn't allocate memory on stuff  *before* someone came around with an usecase which needed that stuff, is not a bug.  

Although if possible I would still do that duplication in the lua layer, so you can opt-in only were this is necessary.

title: Treesitter captures a wrong pattern after applying predicates
